stories.title: South Korea ponders ban on consumption of dog meat

stories.text: Airbnb allows guests to violate its policies at the expense of its hosts.  The billion dollar company gives hosts tools to control who gets to automatically book your home, but l then allows new users to violate this policy with impunity.  Hosts then have no recourse but to cancel the stay themselves - incurring penalties that benefit Airbnb in the process.  Furthermore, Airbnb customer support ambassadors routinely contradict each other's edicts and find sneaky ways to erect roadblocks that keep hosts from raising legitimate concerns on the platform.  The company is built in a house of cards...
stories.title: Airbnb violates policy at hosts expense

stories.text:
Hey there,

I am Kartikey, Editor in Chief at Packt. Please can I have a few minutes of your time? We are developing a weekly, hands-on cybersecurity newsletter as a service to security professionals. As a thank-you gesture, the first 100 survey respondents will win a Packt eBook of their choice!

Survey link: https://forms.office.com/r/vK8kQQBMSk

In this newsletter, I share agenda-setting stories in security, deep practical tutorials, analysis of emerging threats, and threat intelligence resources. Stay security-smart and build skills in as little as 10 minutes!

Read past issues of the SecPro: https://security.packt.com/issues/
stories.title: Get tech eBook of choice (first 100 signups)! Join the SecPro

stories.text:
I've been a "front end" guy since 2007. The pool of jobs I can fit gets smaller every year because I'm not a very good modern front end guy.

I'm not good at animations, responsive layouts, pixel perfection, es6

The simplest task now so complicated, many edge cases.

Things get deprecated (or sunsetted) so fast.

When I open the chrome inspector there's 10 new features which I ignore. It's too much.

I spend so much time googling obscure npm error to fix my local dev environment with each OS or package update.

I lost confidence to apply for jobs because I don't have the will to study the things they will test me for.

Has anyone made that move from front to back, do you feel it's easier?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is Back End easier than Front End (generally)?
